articles.headline: A Global Deal Aimed at Ending Tax Havens Gains Momentum
articles.snippet: Negotiators are coalescing around a 15 percent minimum tax rate, which could be announced at a Friday meeting.
articles.abstract: Negotiators are coalescing around a 15 percent minimum tax rate, which could be announced at a Friday meeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The most sweeping overhaul of the international tax system in a century is poised to take a significant step forward this week, with nearly 140 countries, including Ireland and Estonia, expected to settle on a 15 percent global minimum tax rate.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: A Year After a Jobs Bust, College Students Find a Boom
articles.snippet: Seniors and graduates are again in demand as companies revive recruiting, underscoring the economic premium that comes with a diploma.
articles.abstract: Seniors and graduates are again in demand as companies revive recruiting, underscoring the economic premium that comes with a diploma.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trevaughn Wright-Reynolds, a senior at Colby College in Maine, expected a lengthy job search when he returned to campus in August. “I wasn’t sure how much interest I was going to get,” he said. “I didn’t know what to think of the job market.”
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Coral Murphy Marcos

articles.headline: An Expert on the Criminal Mind, Now He’s Suspected in an Arson Spree
articles.snippet: Amid a series of arson incidents across Northern California this year, a criminology professor was charged with setting a patch of the Sierra Nevada forest ablaze.
articles.abstract: Amid a series of arson incidents across Northern California this year, a criminology professor was charged with setting a patch of the Sierra Nevada forest ablaze.
articles.lead_paragraph: LASSEN NATIONAL FOREST, Calif. — He drove out of the Lumberjacks restaurant parking lot on a Tuesday in August, up Main Street, past the fire station and the gun shop. Then, Gary Maynard left the small city of Susanville in the northeastern corner of California and headed up a steep highway into the Sierra Nevada, where, prosecutors say, he set the forest ablaze.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Livia Albeck-Ripka

articles.headline: A Tiny Gas Meter? The More Mundane the Better for Japan’s Capsule Toys.
articles.snippet: Isolated in their plastic spheres, pint-size reproductions of everyday items feel like a metaphor for Covid-era life.
articles.abstract: Isolated in their plastic spheres, pint-size reproductions of everyday items feel like a metaphor for Covid-era life.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Yoshiaki Yamanishi set out to create the most boring toy imaginable.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno

articles.headline: Weak Employment and Rising Prices Raise the Stakes for the Fed
articles.snippet: The disappointing payrolls report for September came at a high-pressure moment for the central bank, as it balances inflation with missing jobs.
articles.abstract: The disappointing payrolls report for September came at a high-pressure moment for the central bank, as it balances inflation with missing jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: A weak jobs report in September is unlikely to derail the Federal Reserve’s plans to start slowly withdrawing some economic support this year. But it is the latest indication of the delicate balancing act the central bank is facing as it tries to keep inflation tame while allowing the labor market to heal.

articles.headline: Jobs Report Offers Little Reassurance on U.S. Economy
articles.snippet: The gain of 194,000 in September showed the continuing grip of the latest coronavirus wave, though unemployment fell to 4.8 percent.
articles.abstract: The gain of 194,000 in September showed the continuing grip of the latest coronavirus wave, though unemployment fell to 4.8 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Job growth slowed to the year’s weakest pace last month as the latest coronavirus wave dashed hopes of an imminent return to normal for the U.S. economy.

articles.headline: Global Deal to End Tax Havens Moves Ahead as Nations Back 15% Rate
articles.snippet: More than 130 countries agreed to set a minimum tax rate of 15 percent as governments look to end a race to the bottom on corporate taxation.
articles.abstract: More than 130 countries agreed to set a minimum tax rate of 15 percent as governments look to end a race to the bottom on corporate taxation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world’s most powerful nations agreed on Friday to a sweeping overhaul of international tax rules, with officials backing a 15 percent global minimum tax and other changes aimed at cracking down on tax havens that have drained countries of much-needed revenue.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Liz Alderman
